qas.question: Where else beside the SCN cells are independent circadian rhythms also found?
What is the term for the independent clocks?
What is the SCN considered to be in comparison to the peripheral oscillators?
In what body gland are the peripheral oscillators located?
To what do oscillators in the skin respond?
Where are dependent circadian rythems found?
What is the term for dependent clocks?
What in the skin responds to temperature?

context: More-or-less independent circadian rhythms are found <b5_0>in many <a0_0>organs and cells<b5_0/><a0_0/> in the body outside the suprachiasmatic nuclei (SCN), the "<a2_0>master clock<a2_0/>". These clocks, called <a1_0><b6_0>peripheral oscillators<b6_0/><a1_0/>, are found in the <a3_0>adrenal gland<a3_0/>,[citation needed] oesophagus, lungs, liver, pancreas, spleen, thymus, and skin.[citation needed] Though <b7_0>oscillators<b7_0/> in the skin respond to <a4_0>light<a4_0/>, a systemic influence has not been proven. There is also some evidence that the <b8_0>olfactory bulb and prostate<b8_0/> may experience oscillations when cultured, suggesting that these structures may also be weak oscillators.[citation needed]
